quotes.title: The "Peter Principle"
quotes.description: In a hierarchy, every employee tends to rise to his level of incompetence.

quotes.title: Goodhart's law
quotes.description:
Any observed statistical regularity will tend to collapse once pressure is placed upon it for control purposes.
When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.

quotes.title: Parkinson's law
quotes.description: Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion.

quotes.title: Parkinson's law of triviality
quotes.description:
The time spent on any item of the agenda will be in inverse proportion to the sum [of money] involved.

People within an organization commonly or typically give disproportionate weight to trivial issues.

    A.k.a. the bike-shed effect: an average person cannot understand a complex problem, so one assumes that those who work on it understand it. but everyone can visualize a cheap, simple bicycle shed, so planning one can result in endless discussions because everyone involved wants to add a touch and show personal contribution.

    Ambiguity aversion: a preference for known risks over unknown risks.

quotes.title: Gall's law
quotes.description:
A complex system that works is invariably found to have evolved from a simple system that worked. A complex system designed from scratch never works and cannot be patched up to make it work. You have to start over with a working simple system.
	
	Zoals mijn eerdere chef altijd zei: je kunt beter een werkend systeem optimaliseren dan proberen een optimaal systeem werkend te krijgen.

quotes.title: Hofstadter's Law
quotes.description: It always takes longer than you expect, even when you take into account Hofstadter's Law.

quotes.title: Brooks's law
quotes.description: According to Brooks, under certain conditions, an incremental person when added to a project makes it take more, not less time.
